sections.name: Accessing RQL
sections.description: All RQL queries begin from the top level module.

commands.description: Create a new connection to the database server

examples.description: Opens a new connection specifying callbacks both for when the connection is successfully established and in case the connection cannot be opened
Opens a connection using the default host and port but specifying the default database
Opens a connection to localhost:28015 with 'heroes' as the default database

commands.description: Close an open connection

examples.description: Close an open connection to cancel outstanding requests and free the memory associated with the open requests
Close an open connection to cancel outstanding requests and free the memory associated with the open requests
Close an open connection to cancel outstanding requests and free the memory associated with the open requests

commands.description: Close and attempt to reopen a connection. Has the effect of canceling any outstanding request while keeping the connection open

examples.description: Cancel outstanding requests/queries that are no longer needed
Cancel outstanding requests/queries that are no longer needed
Cancel outstanding requests/queries that are no longer needed

commands.description: Change the default database on this connection

examples.description: Change the default database so that we don't need to specify database when referencing a table
Change the default database so that we don't need to specify database when referencing a table
Change the default database so that we don't need to specify database when referencing a table

commands.description: Run a query on this connection

examples.description: Call run on the connection with a query to execute the query. Run will return a cursor from which results may be retrieved.

You can pass a callback function to run which is invoked for each row. If the callback returns true, it gets called again for the next row. If the callback returns false, it will not be invoked again.
Calling run on the query itself will run it on the last opened connection, a handy shortcut used in the rest of these docs

If you are OK with potentially out of date data from all the tables involved in this query and want potentially faster reads, pass a flag allowing out of date data in an options object. The callback and the connection to run this query on can also be passed in the options object. Settings for individual tables will supercede this global setting for all tables in the query.
Use the cursor to lazily iterate over the results. 'cursor' is an iterable object
examples.code:
for doc in conn.run(r.table('marvel')):
    print doc

examples.description: Calling run on the query itself will run it on the last opened connection, a handy shortcut used in the rest of these docs

If you are OK with potentially out of date data from all the tables involved in this query and want potentially faster reads, pass a flag allowing out of date data. Settings for individual tables will supercede this global setting for all tables in the query.
Use the cursor (enumerable) to iterate over the results and print them.
The same as the first example, but uses the most recently opened connection.

If you are OK with potentially out of date data from all the tables involved in this query and want potentially faster reads, pass a flag in an options object allowing out of date data. Settings for individual tables will supercede this global setting for all tables in the query.

commands.description: A run shortcut useful for debugging.

examples.description: runp is equivalent to calling collect on the resulting cursor with console.log as the callback.

commands.description: Lazily iterate over the result set one at a time.

examples.description: Iterate over the results with next. Return true to continue the iteration.
If you only expect one result just use next to process it.
Results will be lazily loaded for large result sets so the next iteration may have to way for asynch I/O.

commands.description: Retreive all results and pass them as an array to the given callback.

examples.description: For small result sets it may be more convienient to processes them at once as an array.

sections.name: Writing data
sections.description: These commands allow inserting, deleting, and updating data.

commands.description:
Insert JSON documents into a table. Accepts a single JSON document or an array of documents.

Insert returns an object that contains at least 2 fields: inserted - the number of documents that were succesfully inserted; errors - the number of errors encountered while inserting. It can also contain a field generated_keys providing a list of generated primary key values

examples.description: Insert a row into a table named 'marvel'.
Insert multiple rows into a table named 'marvel'.
examples.code: r.table('marvel').insert([{ superhero: 'Wolverine', superpower: 'Adamantium' }, { superhero: 'Spiderman', superpower: 'spidy sense' }]).run()

examples.description: Insert a row into a table named 'marvel'. Overwriting if the document already exists.
examples.code: r.table('marvel').insert({ superhero: 'Iron Man', superpower: 'Arc Reactor' }, true).run()

examples.description: Insert a row into a table named 'marvel'.
Insert multiple rows into a table named 'marvel'.
Insert a row into a table named 'marvel'. Overwriting if the document already exists.
Insert a row into a table named 'marvel'.
Insert multiple rows into a table named 'marvel'.
Insert a row into a table named 'marvel'. Overwriting if the document already exists.

Update Superman's age to 30. If attribute 'age' doesn't exist, adds it to the document
Increment every superhero's age. If age doesn't exist, throws an error
Update Superman's age to 30. If attribute 'age' doesn't exist, adds it to the document
Increment every superhero's age. If age doesn't exist, throws an error

commands.description:
Replace documents in a table. Accepts a JSON document or a RQL expression, and replaces the original
document with the new one. The new document must have the same primary key as the original document.

examples.description: Let our heroes join forces to battle evil!
Table 'dc' has a primary key of 'hero_name'. Without specifying it we'll default to 'id'.
The above query is equivalent to this inner join but runs in O(n log(m)) time rather than the O(n * m) time the inner join takes.

sections.name: Aggregation
sections.description: These commands are used to compute smaller values from large sequences

commands.description: Produce a single value from a sequence through repeated application of a reduction function

examples.description: How many enemies have our heroes defeated?
How many enemies have our heroes defeated?
examples.code: r.table('marvel').map(lambda hero: hero['monstersKilled'] + hero['superVillainsVanquished']).reduce(0, lambda acc, val: acc + val).run()

examples.description: How many enemies have our heroes defeated?

commands.description: Count the number of elements in the sequence

examples.description: Just how many super heroes are there?
Just how many super heroes are there?
Just how many super heroes are there?

commands.description: Remove duplicate elements from the sequence

examples.description: How many unique villains have been vanquished by marvel heroes?
How many unique villains have been vanquished by marvel heroes?
How many unique villains have been vanquished by marvel heroes?

commands.description: Partition the sequence into groups and then perform mapping and reduction steps across the groups

examples.description: It's only fair that heroes be compared against their weight class
It's only fair that heroes be compared against their weight class
examples.code:
r.table('marvel').grouped_map_reduce(lambda hero: hero['weightClass'],
  lambda hero: hero.pick('name', 'strength'),
  {'name':'none', 'strength':0},
  lambda acc, hero: r.branch(acc['strength'] < hero['strength'], hero, acc)
).run()

examples.description: It's only fair that heroes be compared against their weight class

commands.description: Groups elements by the values of the given attributes and then applies the given reduction. Though similar to grouped map reduce, groupby takes a standardized object for specifying the reduction. Can be used with a number of predefined common reductions.

examples.description: Using a predefined reduction we can easily find the average strength of members of each weight class
Using a predefined reduction we can easily find the average strength of members of each weight class
Using a predefined reduction we can easily find the average strength of members of each weight class

sections.name: Control Structures
sections.description: These commands provide basic control structures for the composition of complex queries

commands.description: Bind a value to a variable

examples.description: The object passed to let specifies variable names and values to bind to them. The second argument is the expression to evaluate in the context of the bindings.
The object passed to let specifies variable names and values to bind to them. The second argument is the expression to evaluate in the context of the bindings.
The object passed to let specifies variable names and values to bind to them. The second argument is the expression to evaluate in the context of the bindings.

commands.description: Reference a RQL variable

examples.description: Use letVar to reference the name previously bound in an outer let expression
Use letvar to reference the name previously bound in an outer let expression
Use letvar to reference the name previously bound in an outer let expression

commands.description: Evaluate one of two control paths based on the value of an expression

examples.description: Return the manlier of two heroes
examples.code:
r.let({ironman: r.table('marvel').get('IronMan'), thor: r.table('marvel').get('Thor')},
 r.branch(r.letVar('ironman')('manliness').gt(r.letVar('thor')('manliness')),
  r.letVar('ironman'),
  r.letVar('thor')).run()

examples.description: Return the manlier of two heroes
examples.code:
r.let({'ironman': r.table('marvel').get('IronMan'), 'thor': r.table('marvel').get('Thor')},
 r.branch(r.letvar('ironman')['manliness'] > r.letvar('thor')['manliness'],
  r.letvar('ironman'),
  r.letvar('thor')).run()

examples.description: Return the manlier of two heroes

commands.description: Loop over a sequence, evaluating the given write query for each element

examples.description: Now that our heroes have defeated their villains, we can safely remove them from the villain table
Now that our heroes have defedated their villains, we can safely remove them from the villain table
Now that our heroes have defedated their villains, we can safely remove them from the villain table

commands.description: Throw a runtime error

examples.description: Iron Man can't possibly have lost a battle
examples.code:
r.let({ironman: r.table('marvel').get('IronMan')},
 r.branch(r.letVar('ironman')('victories').lt(r.letVar('ironman')('battles')),
  r.error('impossible code path'),
  r.letVar('ironman')
)).run()

examples.description: Iron Man can't possibly have lost a battle
examples.code:
r.let('ironman': r.table('marvel').get('IronMan')},
 r.branch(r.letvar('ironman')['victories'] < r.letVar(:ironman)['battles'],
  r.error('impossible code path'),
  r.letvar('ironman')
)).run()

examples.description: Iron Man can't possibly have lost a battle
